leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 53 CRIMINAL PROCEDURE RULES [rr 1–28]

p.text: [Pt 53 insrt Gaz 150 of 25 September 1987 p 5441]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 GENERAL [rr 1–17]

p.text: [Heading insrt Gaz 63 of 4 May 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[1], effective 4 May 2007]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 1] r 1 Interpretation

p.text: This Part applies only to proceedings in the criminal jurisdiction of the Court.

In this Part, registrar means registrar of the Court in its criminal jurisdiction, and, in relation to any proceedings, means the registrar for the proclaimed place at which the proceedings are heard or to be heard.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 2] r 2 Record of committal or appeal

p.text: Where an accused person is committed for trial to the District Court sitting at a proclaimed place, the registrar of the Local Court at which the accused person was committed for trial shall as soon as practicable forward to the registrar for the proclaimed place a record containing the following information relating to the committal:
the full name of the accused person and any other names recorded in the proceedings in the Local Court as names by which that person is also known,
the date of birth and last known address of the accused person,
whether the accused person is in custody or on bail,
where known to the registrar, the full name, address and telephone number of any solicitor who acted for the accused person in the proceedings resulting in the committal,
the full name and rank of the member of the police force responsible for the proceedings resulting in the committal, and his location,
the short title of the offence for which the accused person was committed, and
the location of the transcription centre to which the tapes of the proceedings resulting in the committal were sent for transcription.
[subr (1) am Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

Where an appellant lodges under section 14(1) or (3) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 a notice of appeal, or an application for leave to appeal, which is to be heard in the District Court sitting at a proclaimed place, the registrar of the Local Court at which was made the conviction or order, or was imposed the sentence, appealed against shall as soon as practicable forward to the registrar for the proclaimed place a record containing the following information relating to the appeal:
the full name of the appellant and any other names recorded in the proceedings in the Local Court as names by which the appellant is also known,
the date of birth and last known address of the appellant,
whether the appellant is in custody or on bail,
where known to the registrar, the full name, address and telephone number of any solicitor who acted for the appellant in the proceedings resulting in the conviction or, order or sentence,
where the informant in the proceedings resulting in the conviction or order was:
a member of the police force — the full name and rank of the member of the police force responsible for those proceedings and his location, or
not a member of the police force — the full name and address of the informant, and, where he laid the information as the holder of an office, the title of that office,
the short title of the offence of which the appellant was convicted, and
the location of the transcription centre to which the tapes of the proceedings resulting in the conviction or, order or sentence were sent for transcription.
[subr (2) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3907 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 2A] r 2A Appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001

leg:heading.title: Appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001

p.text: In this rule:
means an appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001.
[def subst Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]
in respect of an appeal means the person on whom the sentence appealed against was imposed.
[subr (1) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3907]
An appeal shall be lodged by giving notice of the appeal in the approved form to the Registrar of the Local Court at the Downing Centre, Sydney.
[subs (2) am Gaz 52 of 28 March 1991 p 2550 ; Gaz 174 of 31 October 2003 p 10282, effective 31 October 2003]
[subs (3) rep Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3907]
[subs (4) rep Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3907]

The registrar of the Local Court at which was imposed the sentence appealed against shall, as soon as practicable after receiving notice of the appeal, forward to the registrar for the proclaimed place nearest to that Local Court a record containing the following information relating to the appeal:
the full name of the respondent and any other names recorded in the proceedings in the Local Court as names by which the respondent is also known,
the date of birth and last known address of the respondent,
whether the respondent is in custody or on bail,
where known to the registrar, the full name, address and telephone number of any solicitor who acted for the respondent in the proceedings resulting in the sentence,
where the informant in the proceedings resulting in the sentence was:
a member of the police force — the full name and rank of the member of the police force responsible for those proceedings and his location, or
not a member of the police force — the full name and address of the informant, and, where he laid the information as the holder of an office, the title of that office,
the short title of the offence in respect of which the respondent was sentenced, and
the location of the transcription centre to which the tapes of the proceedings resulting in the sentence were sent for transcription.
[subr (5) am Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]
[Heading subst Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]
[r 2A insrt Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1526]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 2B] r 2B Notification of lodging of appeal

p.text: The registrar of the Local Court who receives notice of an appeal, or an application for leave to appeal, lodged under section 14(1) or (3) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 shall immediately thereafter send notification of the lodging of the appeal or application to the Director of Public Prosecutions and the registrar for the proclaimed place at which the appeal or application is to be heard.
[subr (1) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3907 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

The registrar of the Local Court at the Downing Centre, Sydney shall, immediately after notice of an appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 is given to him, send notification of the lodging of the appeal to the registrar for the proclaimed place at which the appeal is to be heard.
[subr (2) am Gaz of 28 March 1991 p 2550 ; Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3908 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]
[r 2B insrt Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 2C] r 2C Registrar of Local Court to order transcript

leg:heading.title: Registrar of Local Court to order transcript

p.text: Where, consequent on any proceedings in a Local Court:
a person is committed for trial to the District Court,
an appellant lodges under section 14(1) or (3) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 a notice of appeal or an application for leave to appeal, or
the Director of Public Prosecutions lodges an appeal under section 23(1) of that Act,
the registrar of the Local Court shall as soon as practicable request preparation of a transcript of the proceedings.

[r 2C insrt Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527 ; am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3908 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003; Gaz 174 of 31 October 2003 p 10282, effective 31 October 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 3] r 3 Service of documents

p.text: In this rule:
means a true copy of a document (including a notice of listing) to be served.
means the person to be served with a document.
means service of a document required or permitted by or under any Act or these rules or by any other of the Court to be served in the conduct of any proceedings.
Except where otherwise provided by or under any Act or these rules, service may be effected:
on an accused person, appellant, or respondent to an appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 — by a member of the police force or a Sheriff's Officer, or
on any other person, by any person over the age of 16 years.
[subr (2) am Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]
Service may be personal, but need not be personal unless required by the rules or any order.
Personal service may be effected by delivering a copy to the party personally.
A copy may be delivered to a person by handing it to him or by leaving it in his presence and informing him of its nature.

Except where personal service is required, service may be effected by delivering a copy at the residence or place of business of the party, to a person apparently not less than 16 years old and apparently residing at that residence or employed at that place of business.
It shall not be necessary to the regular service of any document that the original thereof be produced to any person.
Where a solicitor acts for a party, service on the party may be effected by:
delivering a copy to the solicitor,
leaving a copy, addressed to the solicitor, at his office,
sending a copy by post addressed to the solicitor at his office, or

where the solicitor has an exchange box in a document exchange, in the State, of Australian Document Exchange Pty Limited — leaving a copy, addressed to the solicitor, in that exchange box or at another exchange box for transmission to that exchange box.
Service on a party who is in custody at an institution may be effected by delivery of a copy at the institution to the officer in charge thereof.
Service:
[repealed]
by leaving a copy at an exchange box shall be deemed to be effected on a day 2 days after the copy is so left.
[subr (10) am Gaz 122 of 6 October 1995 p 7160]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 4] r 4 Party in custody

p.text: Where for the purposes of any proceedings:
a document is handed, or information or a request is conveyed, to the officer in charge of an institution for delivery to a party who is in custody at that institution, or
a party who is in custody at an institution hands a document, or conveys information or a request, to the officer in charge of that institution for delivery to the registrar,
the officer shall ensure that the document, information or request is so delivered as soon as practicable.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 5] r 5 Representation

p.text: A legal practitioner whose authority to act for a party in any proceedings has not been terminated by the party shall not, without the leave of the Court, cease to act for the party unless he has given reasonable notice of his intention to so cease to act to all parties to the proceedings, the registrar and the Criminal Listing Director.
[subr (1) am Gaz 26 of 1 March 1996 p 944]

An application for the leave of the Court as mentioned in subrule (1) shall be made on notice to all parties to the proceedings, the registrar and the Criminal Listing Director of the day and the place where, and the grounds on which, the leave is to be sought.
Non-payment of professional costs or counsel's fees shall not of itself constitute adequate grounds on which the Court may grant leave as mentioned in subrule (1) .

A statement by a legal practitioner that he desires for ethical reasons to cease to act shall, without any explanation on being required by the Court, constitute adequate grounds for the granting of leave as mentioned in subrule (1) , and the fact that such a statement has been made by the solicitor shall be recorded on the Court file.
[subr (4) am Gaz 26 of 1 March 1996 p 944]

A solicitor or, where a barrister acts uninstructed by any solicitor, a barrister who acts for a party in any proceedings and has reason at any time to believe that he has lost contact with the party shall as soon as practicable, in writing, so inform every other party, the registrar and the Criminal Listing Director.
[subr (5) insrt Gaz 57 of 4 May 1990 p 3545 ; am Gaz 26 of 1 March 1996 p 944]

Without limiting the generality of subrule (5) , a solicitor or, where a barrister acts uninstructed by any solicitor, a barrister who acts for a party in any proceedings shall, not less than 1 month nor more than 2 months before the date fixed for the hearing of the proceedings, ascertain whether he remains in contact with the party.
[subr (6) insrt Gaz 57 of 4 May 1990 p 3545 ; am Gaz 26 of 1 March 1996 p 944]
[subr (7) rep Gaz 81 of 1 July 2005 r 3 and Sch 1, effective 15 August 2005]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 6] r 6 Listing

p.text: At the listing of any proceedings the Court may hear the proceedings or may give directions for the proper, speedy and convenient hearing of the proceedings as it may determine, and may adjourn the listing of the proceedings to another date.
In adjourning the listing of any proceedings to another date the Court shall so far as practicable liaise with the Criminal Listing Director.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 7] r 7 Venue

p.text: This rule applies subject to any order made by the Supreme Court under Section 577 of the Crimes Act 1900, or by the Attorney-General, in respect of the venue of any proceedings.
Subject to this rule, the venue for the hearing of any proceedings shall be:
in the case of a person committed for trial or sentence to the Court sitting at a proclaimed place — that proclaimed place, or

in the case of an appeal under section 11 , or an application for leave to appeal under section 12 or 13 , of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001, the proclaimed place nearest to the Local Court at which was made the conviction or order or was imposed the sentence, appealed, or sought to be appealed, against, or

in the case of an appeal under section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001 — the nearest proclaimed place to the Local Court at which was imposed the sentence appealed against.
[subr (2) am Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527 ; Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3908 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

Whether or not the hearing of any proceedings has commenced, the Court may, on the application of a party or of its own motion, on terms order that the venue of the proceedings be changed to another proclaimed place.

Notwithstanding anything in subrule (2) , and without limiting subrule (3) , the Court may, on the application of a party or of its own motion, direct that any proceedings for hearing at a specified proclaimed place comprised within a District are to be heard at another proclaimed place that is comprised within the same District.
[subr (4) insrt Gaz 152 of 15 December 1995 p 8657]
The powers of the Court under subrule (4) may, in respect of a District, be exercised by the Court, or by the registrar in the criminal jurisdiction for that District.
[subr (5) insrt Gaz 152 of 15 December 1995 p 8657 ; am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909]

level.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 7.5] Change of venue in criminal proceedings

p.text: Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 7.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 r 10.
(ACT) Crimes Act 1900 s 577.

heading.title: Change of venue in criminal proceedings

p.text: Any application for a change of venue must be made in accordance with the procedures set down in r 10 . In the course of any such application, the court must apply the test set out in s 577 of the Crimes Act which requires that it be satisfied that a fair or unprejudiced trial cannot be held unless there is a change of venue or alternatively, that there are other reasons which deem a change of venue expedient. There is a long standing principle that a criminal trial should occur in the place where the crime is alleged to have been committed and the accused bears a heavy onus to establish that such a course is not appropriate: see generallyR v Dorrington [1969] 1 NSWR 381 at 382–3, cited with approval in R v Katavich (NSWCCA, Hunt CJ, Smart and McInerney, No 60431/96, 25 September 1996, unreported, BC9604526).

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 8] r 8 Subpoenas

p.text: [r 8 rep Gaz 63 of 4 May 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[2], effective 4 May 2007]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 8A] r 8A Tendering bundles of documents

p.text: If a party to proceedings seeks to tender more that one document to the Court at the same time (a bundle of documents), the party must:
number each document in the bundle of documents with a consecutive whole number commencing with “1”, and
prepare a schedule for the bundle of documents that provides a brief description of each document in the bundle next to the number for the document allocated as provided by paragraph (a), and
provide a copy of the schedule and the bundle of documents both to the Court and to each other party to the proceedings.
[r 8A insrt Gaz 119 of 19 July 2002 p 5463, effective 19 July 2002]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 9] r 9 Return of exhibits

p.text: Exhibits in any proceedings, whether produced on subpoena or otherwise, may be returned to the person who produced them to the Court or registrar:
where the Court makes an order for the return of the exhibits, forthwith, and

where, within a period of 90 days after sentence is passed or deferred or a final order is made, the Court makes no order for the return or retention of the exhibits, and no notice is given to the registrar of any appeal in the proceedings, forthwith after the expiration of that period.
[subr (1) am Gaz 119 of 19 July 2002 p 5463, effective 19 July 2002]

A person to whom exhibits may be returned under subrule (1) shall obtain the return of, and give to the registrar a receipt for the exhibits as soon as practicable, and the registrar shall be responsible for the safe custody of any exhibits in his keeping for a period only of 14 days after the first day on which the exhibits may be so returned.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10] r 10 Pre-trial applications

p.text: Any application to the Court in relation to any proceedings which may practicably be made before the day appointed for the hearing of the proceedings shall be made before that day.
An application may be made, and the Court may make orders with regard to the application, before the day appointed for the hearing, where the application is:
for adjournment,
to quash or stay an indictment,
to demur to an indictment,
for separate trials,
for severance of counts,
for change of venue,
to set aside a subpoena,
for leave to withdraw an appeal under section 67 of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001.
for directions generally,
for an order under the Bail Act 1978 , or
for an order under rule 11(1) .
[subr (2) am Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527 ; Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

Subject to subrule (4) , an application referred to in subrule (1) shall be made by filing notice of motion supported, unless the Court otherwise orders, by an affidavit or affidavits as to the facts and grounds upon which the application is made.
A party may make an application referred to in subrule (1) without previously filing or serving notice of the motion:
where the preparation of the notice, or the filing or service of the notice (as the case may be), would cause undue delay or other mischief to the applicant,
where no date has been fixed for the hearing of the proceedings, or of any proceedings ancillary to the proceedings, and all parties to the proceedings consent to the order applied for, or
where the Court gives leave to the party so to do.
[subr (4) am Gaz 77 of 22 April 1988 p 2312]
Notice of a motion shall:
state the date and time when, and the place where, the motion is to be made, that date, time and place having been obtained by the applicant from the registrar,
where the Court has made an order under subrule (6) , bear a note of the order made,
state concisely the nature of the order sought, and
state concisely the grounds on which the order is sought, or refer to the affidavit in which those grounds are contained.
[subr (5) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909]

Unless the Court otherwise orders, a party filing a notice of motion shall serve the notice, and every affidavit in support of the motion, on each other party to the proceedings not less than 3 days before the date fixed for the motion.
[subr (6) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909]
An application referred to in subrule (1) in relation to any proceedings which are expected to be heard at a place where the Court does not usually sit on every Court day may be made in Sydney.

The provisions of the rule do not give a trial judge power to give an "advance ruling" as to the way in which a particular discretion to exclude evidence might be exercised: TKWJ v R (2002) 193 ALR 7; 76 ALJR 1579 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10A] r 10A Application to reopen proceedings

p.text: An application of a party as referred to in section 43(2) of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999 shall, unless the Court otherwise orders, be made on notice of motion.
[subr (1) am Gaz 67 of 28 March 2002 p 2044 effective 28 March 2002]
Rule 10(5) , (6) and (7) shall apply to a notice of motion referred to in subrule (1) as if the notice were filed under rule 10 .
[r 10A insrt Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1527]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10B] r 10B Applications relating to trial by judge alone under Criminal Procedure Act

leg:heading.title: Applications relating to trial by judge alone under Criminal Procedure Act

p.text: An application referred to in section 132(1) or 132A(3) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 in respect of any proceedings must be in writing in or to the effect of the approved form.
[r 10B subst SI 395 of 2012 r 3, effective 24 August 2012]
Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 10B.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 s 32(1), s 32(4), (5).
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 r 10B.

Sections 32(1) and (5) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 allows an accused person charged with an indictable offence to elect, in certain circumstances, to be tried by a judge alone. While it has been held that compliance with the provisions of r 10B (which facilitate such an election) is mandatory (as to which see R v Perry (1993) 29 NSWLR 589 ) the nature of any non-compliance must be taken into account and may require the court to adopt a more flexible approach: see R v Birlut (1996) 39 NSWLR 1. An election by an accused person for trial by judge alone pursuant to the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 must, pursuant to s 32(4) of that Act, be made before the date fixed for the person's trial. It has been held that when a matter is stood out of the daily trial list and re-listed for a new date, that new date becomes the date fixed for the person's trial for the purposes of that section: R v Coles (1993) 31 NSWLR 550 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10C] r 10C Notice under section 67 or 99 of the Evidence Act 1995

leg:heading.title: Notice under section 67 or 99 of the Evidence Act 1995

p.text: Rule 31.5 of the Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 applies in respect of proceedings in the criminal jurisdiction of the Court.
[r 10C insrt Gaz 122 of 6 October 1995 p 7160 ; am Gaz 81 of 1 July 2005 r 3 and Sch 1, effective 15 August 2005]
Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 10C.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 Rule 31.5.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 ss 67, 99.
Rule 31.5 of the UCPR deals with notices for the purpose of ss 67 and 99 of the Evidence Act 1995.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10D] r 10D Manner of presenting indictments

p.text: An indictment may be presented by filing a copy of the indictment with the registrar.

If an indictment is filed with the registrar, a copy of the indictment must be served on each accused person or the accused person's legal representative within 14 days after the filing of the indictment.
Without limiting the generality of rule 3, an indictment may be filed or served by letter or facsimile.
In this rule, accused person's legal representative means:
a solicitor who acts for the accused, or
if a barrister acts for the accused person uninstructed by a solicitor, the barrister.
[r 10D insrt Gaz 143 of 21 September 2001 p 7892, effective 19 November 2001]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10E] r 10E Time for presenting indictments

p.text: [r 10E rep Gaz 151 of 19 October 2007 r 2 and Sch 1, effective 19 October 2007]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 10F] r 10F Applications for orders under section 54(3)(b) of Criminal Procedure Act 1986

leg:heading.title: Applications for orders under section 54(3)(b) of Criminal Procedure Act 1986

p.text: An application for an order under section 54(3)(b) of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 to extend the time for filing an indictment:
must be made before the time for filing the indictment has expired, and
may be made in Court or by written application to the Court.
[r 10F insrt Gaz 143 of 21 September 2001 p 7892, effective 19 November 2001]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 11] r 11 Evidence

p.text: The Court may order that an enquiry by way of a voir dire into the admissibility of any evidence or as to the capacity of a witness to give evidence be had, before the trial Judge, at any stage of any proceedings whether before or after the jury is empanelled.
Before commencing any enquiry ordered under subrule (1) the Court shall require the accused person, if he has not already pleaded to the charge against him, to so plead.
Unless the Court otherwise orders, a party shall make any statement he intends to make, and give any evidence he intends to give, before he adduces any other evidence.
The Court may in any proceedings order, on terms, that evidence or submissions may be received by telephone, video link or other form of communication.
[subr (4) insrt Gaz 149 of 8 December 1995 p 8468]
Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 11.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 r 10, r 11.
(NSW) Criminal Appeal Act 1912 s 5F.

The purpose of r 11 , in combination with r 10 , is to facilitate the resolution of matters in advance of the trial in an effort to minimise delay and inconvenience in the course of the trial itself. The operation of r 11 is not necessarily limited to those matters where a voir dire is required, but shall include legal argument as to the admissibility of evidence: R v Waterhouse (1992) 62 A Crim R 59 ; R v Steffan (1993) 30 NSWLR 633 . Any ruling in respect of evidentiary matters which is made pursuant to r 11 is not binding during the course of the trial itself and does not constitute an “interlocutory judgment” within the meaning of s 5F of the Criminal Appeal Act 1912: R v Steffan, above. There are, however, some limits on its operation, as to which see R v GLC [2000] NSWCCA 99; BC200001596 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 11A] r 11A View of real property

p.text: The Court has the same powers as the Supreme Court has to make an order for a view of real property for the purposes of any proceedings.
[r 11A insrt Gaz 73 of 27 May 1994 p 2533 ]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 12] r 12 Entry and recording of judgments, orders, sentences, directions and recommendations

leg:heading.title: Entry and recording of judgments, orders, sentences, directions and recommendations

p.text: Any judgment, order, sentence, direction or recommendation given or made by a Judge in any proceedings shall be entered on:
the indictment in the proceedings,
the appropriate court file, or
the appropriate computer record
and that entry shall, when signed by the Judge or entered on the appropriate computer record, be the record of the judgment, order, sentence, direction or recommendation.
[r 12 subst Gaz 167 of 9 November 2007 r 2 and Sch 1, effective 9 November 2007]
Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 12.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Justices Act 1902 s 51A.
(NSW) Criminal Procedure Act 1986 Div 5, Division 2, s 111(1).
(NSW) District Court Rules 1973 Pt 53 r 12.

The record of the District Court in relation to trials upon indictment is the indictment itself. Orders are noted upon the indictment: Stephens v R (1990) 48 A Crim R 323 at 327; BC9002326 per Allen J, with whom the other members of the Court of Criminal Appeal agreed. The effect of s 51A of the Justices Act 1902 * and Pt 53 r 12 is that the s 51A "Committal for sentence" form is assimilated to the indictment so that, once the sentence is recorded on it, it becomes the record of the sentence: see R v CJP [2003] NSWCCA 187; BC200304064 ; Erceg v District Court of New South Wales [2003] NSWCA 379; BC200308006 at [22], [23], [116] . The “judge” referred to in r 12 is the judge of the District Court. Where the particulars have not been entered upon the indictment and the orders made have not passed into record, the court retains the power to set them aside: R v Billington [1980] VR 625 ; R v Cross [1973] QB 937; [1973] 2 All ER 920 ; Erceg v District Court of New South Wales , above, at [22].

The Justices Act 1902 was repealed by the Justices Legislation Repeal and Amendment Act 2001 with effect from 7 July 2003. The committal for sentence procedure is now found in Div 5 , Pt 2, Ch 3 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986. Section 111(1) provides that the registrar must give the appropriate officer of the court to which an accused person has been committed for sentence “the documents required by the rules”. Clause 16 of the Local Courts (Criminal and Applications Procedure) Rule 2003 identifies the documents required to be forwarded pursuant to s 111(1) . The documents do not include any document which would perform the function of the s 51A form. Division 2 of Pt 3 of the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 sets out detailed provisions concerning the presentation of the indictment upon the committal of an accused person for trial. It does not extend to a committal for sentence. It has been suggested that it would be highly desirable if the Criminal Procedure Act 1986 was amended to give statutory recognition to the document upon which the sentence pronounced in committal for sentence procedures can be recorded to ensure there can be no further controversy about what constitutes the record in such matters: Erceg v District Court of New South Wales [2003] NSWCA 379; BC200308006 at [170]–[172] per McColl JA.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 12A] r 12A Notice of result of appeal

p.text: As soon as practicable after the Court gives judgment in respect of, or makes an order or gives any leave which has the effect of disposing of, an appeal under section 11 or section 23(1) of the Crimes (Local Courts Appeal and Review) Act 2001, the registrar shall send notice of the judgment, order or leave to the Magistrate who recorded the conviction, made the order, or imposed the sentence, appealed against.
[r 12A insrt Gaz 34 of 23 March 1989 p 1528 ; am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909 ; Gaz 54 of 28 February 2003 p 3571, effective 7 July 2003]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 13] r 13 Recognizances

p.text: The registrar shall:
maintain a record of every recognizance entered into by order of the Court, and
where money is paid to the registrar as required by a condition of a recognizance, maintain a record of the payment and disburse the money to the person entitled to it.

Where a recognizance entered into by order of the Court is conditioned to require a party to do or refrain from doing any thing or to suffer the doing of any thing by any person, and it is alleged that the party is in breach of that condition, the person so alleged shall without delay so advise the registrar.
Unless the Court otherwise orders, the registrar shall, in respect of a recognizance:
on receiving any advice given under subrule (2) , or
on becoming aware of a breach of a condition requiring payment of money to the registrar,
without delay submit a report on the advice or breach to the Judge who required the recognizance to be entered into, or, if that Judge be not available, to the Chief Judge or another Judge.

After considering any report submitted to him under subrule (3) , a Judge may if he thinks fit direct that the party the subject of the report be brought before him or another Judge or that no action be taken in respect of the report, or may make such other directions as to him seem appropriate.

Where a Judge directs under subrule (4) that a party be brought before a Judge, the registrar shall without delay give notice to the party to that effect, and shall include in that notice the place and time at which the party is so required to appear.

At a place and time notified under subrule (5) , or at any other place and time to which the matter is adjourned, a Judge may deal according to law with a party who is in breach of a condition of a recognizance whether or not the Judge is the Judge who directed that the party be brought before a Judge.

The certificate of the registrar as to the amount of any money paid to him as required by a condition of a recognizance, the date of any such payment, and any amount remaining due to be paid under the condition, shall be evidence of the facts stated in the certificate.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 14] r 14 Interpreters

p.text: This rule applies to an interpreter whose services are provided by arrangement with the registrar for the assistance of the Court in the translation of evidence given in any proceedings.
[subr (1) am Gaz 68 of 11 June 1999 p 3909]
This rule does not apply to an interpreter who is engaged to assist a party.

An interpreter to whom this rule applies shall, when attending at the Court for the purpose of the proceedings, report to the Sheriff's Officer in charge at the Court or to the Associate to the presiding Judge.

An interpreter to whom this rule applies shall not, without the direction or permission of the presiding Judge, make his services available to, or communicate with, a party to the proceedings or the representative of such a party.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 15] r 15 Functions of Assistant Registrars

p.text: An assistant registrar at a place that is a proclaimed place shall have the functions of the registrar for that proclaimed place.
[subr 15 am Gaz 63 of 4 May 2007 r 2 and Sch 1[3], effective 4 May 2007]
An assistant registrar at a place that is not a proclaimed place shall have the function only of issuing subpoenas.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 16] r 16 Relevant factors for appearance by audio visual link: section 5BA of Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998

leg:heading.title: Relevant factors for appearance by audio visual link: section 5BA of Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998

p.text: The following are specified as additional factors that the Court is to take into account in determining whether it is in the interests of the administration of justice to make a direction under section 5BA(1) of the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 that an accused child detainee is to appear before the Court by audio visual link:
the nature of the proceedings concerned,
the right of the accused child detainee to be given the fullest opportunity to be heard and to participate in the proceedings,
whether the accused child detainee would be significantly advantaged or disadvantaged if directed to appear by audio visual link,
the availability of Judges of the Court to hear the proceedings by audio visual link,
the need for the accused child detainee’s lawyer to obtain initial or detailed instructions from the accused child detainee,
the need for the accused child detainee’s lawyer to discuss a brief of evidence with the accused child detainee,
[repealed]
the maturity of the accused child detainee,
the accused child detainee’s need for the support of a parent, carer or other support person during the proceedings,
the wishes of the accused child detainee,
[repealed]
any special needs of the accused child detainee, including the impact of any intellectual or physical disability or mental illness that the accused child detainee may have,
whether the accused child detainee requires the assistance of an interpreter and the availability of an appropriate interpreter,
[repealed]
[repealed]
[repealed]
[repealed]
[subr (1) am SI 218 of 2012 s 3, effective 1 June 2012]
Expressions used in this rule that are defined in section 3 of the Evidence (Audio and Audio Visual Links) Act 1998 have the meanings set out in that section.
[r 16 insrt Gaz 120 of 16 July 2004 p 5910, effective 16 July 2004 ; am SI 218 of 2012 s 3, effective 1 June 2012]
Legislation cited in [DCR Pt 53 r 16.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Children's Court Rule 2000 r 32A.
See also Children’s Court Rules 2000 r 32A .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCR Pt 53 r 17] r 17 Elections under section 11A of Mental Health (Criminal Procedure) Act 1990

leg:heading.title: Elections under section 11A of Mental Health (Criminal Procedure) Act 1990

p.text: An election made by a person under section 11A of the Mental Health (Criminal Procedure) Act 1990 must be made in writing in or to the effect of the approved form.
[r 17 insrt Gaz 147 of 17 September 2004 p 7550, effective 17 September 2004]
